meta.notes: Milestone-first genome (0â€“4y). Domains appear only as tags. Integrated missing Literacy, Numeracy, Executive Function, Fine Motor precision milestones, and added Art and Music domains. Existing nodes preserved and normalized.

nodes.name: Birth: Reflexive responses
nodes.description: At birth, infants display reflexive behaviors (like startling at loud sounds, rooting for a nipple, grasping a finger). These automatic responses help them survive and form the basis for later voluntary movements.
exitCriteria: Exhibits key newborn reflexes (Moro, rooting, grasping)
signals: Newborn reflexes (startle, suck) are present from day one
Gradually becomes more calm with gentle soothing as reflexes integrate
activities: Provide gentle support and comfort (swaddling, skin-to-skin contact) to help newborn adjust
Offer opportunities for reflexes to be triggered naturally (touch cheek to elicit rooting) and ensure a safe, comforting environment

_orig.name: Birth: Reflexive responses
exitCriteria: Exhibits key newborn reflexes (Moro, rooting, grasping)
_orig.description: At birth, infants display reflexive behaviors (like startling at loud sounds, rooting for a nipple, grasping a finger). These automatic responses help them survive and form the basis for later voluntary movements.

nodes.name: Sensory Processing & Integration
nodes.description: Progression of sensory milestones and play experiences across modalities (visual, auditory, tactile, vestibular, olfactory/gustatory).

nodes.name: Tracks objects horizontally ~90Â°
exitCriteria: Follows moving object ~90Â° smoothly with eyes
signals: Fixates then follows side-to-side
activities: Slow side-to-side rattle 25â€“35cm away

nodes.name: Tracks objects ~180Â° across midline
exitCriteria: Follows toy across midline
signals: Head + eyes track full arc
activities: Bright toy arc from shoulder to shoulder

nodes.name: Recognizes familiar faces/pictures
exitCriteria: Shows preference or points to familiar person/picture
signals: Smiles, reaches, points to parentâ€™s photo
activities: Family photo peekaboo book

nodes.name: Discriminates size/shape differences in view
exitCriteria: Selects bigger/smaller when prompted 3/4 trials
signals: Prefers larger snack piece when offered
activities: Big/small picture match, shape sort sight game

nodes.name: Figureâ€“ground: finds target in visual clutter
exitCriteria: Finds 3 hidden pictures in a busy page
signals: Scans systematically, points correctly
activities: I spy mats, treasure picture hunts

nodes.name: Startles to loud sound
exitCriteria: Consistent startle to clap or loud sound
signals: Blink, arm fling, cry
activities: Soft clap 2â€“3m away (safety first)

nodes.name: Turns to sound source
exitCriteria: Turns toward the correct side 3/4 trials
signals: Head turn to rattle out of sight
activities: Left/right shaker localization

nodes.name: Responds to own name
exitCriteria: Looks/voices when name called 3 times
signals: Stops, looks to caller
activities: Circle-time name game

nodes.name: Discriminates common environmental sounds
exitCriteria: Matches 3 sounds to pictures correctly
signals: Says/points bell! car!
activities: Sound lotto, mystery sound box

nodes.name: Explores textures with tolerance
exitCriteria: Touches 3+ textures without withdrawal
signals: Pats furry, bumpy, smooth items
activities: Texture board, scarf bin

nodes.name: Engages in messy sensory play
exitCriteria: Plays with wet/soft media for 2+ minutes
signals: Touches, squishes, then explores more
activities: Finger paint, foam play, jelly bags

nodes.name: Sorts by texture (rough/smooth/soft)
exitCriteria: Sorts 6 items into 2 correct texture groups
signals: Feels, compares, then sorts consistently
activities: Texture cards to baskets, feel and match

nodes.name: Calms with rocking/movement
exitCriteria: Soothes within 2 minutes of gentle rocking
signals: Quiets, relaxes tone
activities: Rocking chair, rhythmic sway

nodes.name: Enjoys swinging/bouncing play
exitCriteria: Seeks swing/bounce repeatedly
signals: Laughs, requests more
activities: Toddler swing, lap-bounce rhymes

nodes.name: Seeks balance challenges (walks line/beam)
exitCriteria: Walks taped line 2â€“3m without stepping off
signals: Arms out, steadying self
activities: Tape line, low balance beam, stepping stones

nodes.name: Reacts to strong smells/tastes
exitCriteria: Shows clear like/dislike reaction
signals: Turns head away or toward smell
activities: Vanilla/lemon smell cards, herb garden sniff

nodes.name: Explores novel flavors safely
exitCriteria: Accepts small tastes of 3 new foods
signals: Touches, licks, small bites
activities: Taste rainbow (teacher-led), safe dips

nodes.name: Identifies 2â€“3 familiar food smells
exitCriteria: Names banana/coffee/vanilla by smell
signals: Says label on sniffing jar
activities: Smell jars with picture choices

nodes.name: Attends to bold colors & contrast
exitCriteria: Sustains gaze on colorful/contrast target for several seconds
signals: Tracks colorful target, reaches for it
activities: High-contrast books/cards, color mobiles

nodes.name: Explores textures with hands (art media-ready)
exitCriteria: Touches 3 textures without distress
signals: Pats, squeezes, strokes varied textures
activities: Dry collage tray (felt/foil), brush on dry paper

nodes.name: Intentional mark-making (chunky tools)
exitCriteria: Makes repeated marks on purpose
signals: Presses crayon/dauber to leave marks
activities: Jumbo crayons, vertical easel strokes

nodes.name: Matches basic colors in context
exitCriteria: Matches 3/4 trials with 2â€“3 color choices
signals: Puts red on red mat, blue on blue
activities: Color mat sorting, lid-to-cup color match

nodes.name: Dips & paints with a wide brush
exitCriteria: Dipâ€“apply cycle repeated 3+ times
signals: Holds brush, dips in cup, paints on paper
activities: Single-color brush work, water painting outdoors

nodes.name: Creates simple collage with 2â€“3 materials
exitCriteria: Arranges and glues multiple pieces intentionally
signals: Places chosen shapes with purpose
activities: Large glue stick + pre-cut shapes

nodes.name: Represents familiar object/person
exitCriteria: Adult can identify intended object with childâ€™s label
signals: Adds features (rays to sun, door to square)
activities: Guided draw-and-tell, add details to template

nodes.name: Intentionally makes sounds with a shaker
exitCriteria: Deliberately shakes to produce sound 3+ times
signals: Looks at shaker, shakes, pauses, re-shakes
activities: Two-shaker turn-taking, hide-and-shake

nodes.name: Bangs drum/table in controlled play
exitCriteria: Alternates 4â€“6 strikes with brief pauses
signals: Varies volume/tempo on purpose
activities: Soft/loud copy-me, stopâ€“go cues

nodes.name: Alternates between two instruments on cue
exitCriteria: Switches correctly 3/4 cue changes
signals: Looks to cued instrument and plays it
activities: Red/Blue cue cards, call-and-switch song

nodes.name: Identifies common instruments by sound/picture
exitCriteria: Correctly IDs 3 instruments across trials
signals: Says/points drum, bell, xylophone
activities: Instrument sound lotto, what made that sound?

nodes.name: Claps/steps roughly to a steady beat
exitCriteria: Maintains beat Â±1 beat over 8â€“10 claps/steps with model
signals: Syncs briefly, re-joins when cued
activities: Marching parade, clap-along tapping

nodes.name: Repeats a simple rhythm pattern (echo)
exitCriteria: Accurate echo 3/5 tries (tempo free)
signals: Listens, reproduces short rhythm cells
activities: Echo-clap, drum questionâ€“answer phrases

nodes.name: Imitates simple pitch contours (up/down)
exitCriteria: Correct up/down direction 3/4 echoes
signals: Slides voice up on up, down on down
activities: High sky/low ground echo, xylophone 3-bar copy

nodes.name: Matches a target note within small range
exitCriteria: Matches 2 of 3 target notes (within a third)
signals: Adjusts voice to teacherâ€™s pitch
activities: Echo single notes with piano/bells

nodes.name: Lifts head in prone (brief)
nodes.description: When placed on the tummy, the infant briefly lifts their head up against gravity. This early gross motor milestone builds neck strength and marks the beginning of anti-gravity control.
exitCriteria: Holds head up for a few seconds during tummy time
signals: Lifts head in prone easily
Begins to lift head momentarily during tummy time
activities: Allow plenty of floor time to practice movements freely
Use toys to motivate reaching, rolling, crawling or walking

_orig.name: Lifts head in prone (brief)
exitCriteria: Holds head up for a few seconds during tummy time

signals: Lifts head in prone easily

activities: Allow plenty of floor time to practice movements freely
Use toys to motivate reaching, rolling, crawling or walking

nodes.name: Props on forearms (lifts chest)
nodes.description: Lying on the tummy, the baby pushes up onto forearms, lifting the chest off the surface. This milestone indicates growing upper body strength and better head control.
exitCriteria: Pushes up onto forearms for several seconds
signals: Lifts head in prone (brief) easily
Begins to push up onto forearms during tummy time
activities: Allow plenty of floor time to practice movements freely
Use toys to motivate reaching, rolling, crawling or walking

_orig.name: Props on forearms (lifts chest)
exitCriteria: Pushes up onto forearms for several seconds
_orig.description: Lying on the tummy, the baby pushes up onto forearms, lifting the chest off the surface. This milestone indicates growing upper body strength and better head control.
signals: Lifts head in prone (brief) easily
Begins to push up onto forearms during tummy time
activities: Allow plenty of floor time to practice movements freely
Use toys to motivate reaching, rolling, crawling or walking

nodes.name: Rolls from tummy to back
nodes.description: From a prone (tummy-down) position, the infant learns to roll onto their back. This first roll typically happens accidentally at first and then becomes intentional, helping baby explore movement and position changes.
exitCriteria: Rolls completely over without help
signals: Props on forearms (lifts chest) easily
Begins to roll from tummy to back occasionally
activities: Allow plenty of floor time to practice movements freely
Use toys to motivate reaching, rolling, crawling or walking

_orig.name: Rolls from tummy to back
exitCriteria: Rolls completely over without help
_orig.description: From a prone (tummy-down) position, the infant learns to roll onto their back. This first roll typically happens accidentally at first and then becomes intentional, helping baby explore movement and position changes.
signals: Props on forearms (lifts chest) easily
Begins to roll from tummy to back occasionally
activities: Allow plenty of floor time to practice movements freely
Use toys to motivate reaching, rolling, crawling or walking

nodes.name: Rolls from back to tummy
nodes.description: Now the baby can roll from their back onto their tummy. This direction typically comes a little later and requires more strength and coordination, indicating improved core and neck control.
exitCriteria: Rolls completely over without help
signals: Rolls from tummy to back easily
Begins to twist and roll from back to side or tummy
activities: Allow plenty of floor time to practice movements freely
Use toys to motivate reaching, rolling, crawling or walking

_orig.name: Rolls from back to tummy
exitCriteria: Rolls completely over without help
_orig.description: Now the baby can roll from their back onto their tummy. This direction typically comes a little later and requires more strength and coordination, indicating improved core and neck control.
signals: Rolls from tummy to back easily
Begins to twist and roll from back to side or tummy
activities: Allow plenty of floor time to practice movements freely
Use toys to motivate reaching, rolling, crawling or walking

nodes.name: Sits with support
nodes.description: With pillows or a caregiver holding, the baby can maintain a sitting position. Supported sitting helps strengthen trunk muscles and is a step toward independent sitting.
exitCriteria: Sits propped up (with support) for a short time
signals: Rolls from tummy to back easily
Begins to sit upright when propped, though still wobbly
activities: Prop the baby in a seated position with pillows for short periods under supervision
Encourage reaching for toys while seated (with support) to improve balance

_orig.name: Sits with support
exitCriteria: Sits propped up (with support) for a short time
_orig.description: With pillows or a caregiver holding, the baby can maintain a sitting position. Supported sitting helps strengthen trunk muscles and is a step toward independent sitting.
signals: Rolls from tummy to back easily
Begins to sit upright when propped, though still wobbly
activities: Prop the baby in a seated position with pillows for short periods under supervision
Encourage reaching for toys while seated (with support) to improve balance

nodes.name: Sits independently (unsupported)
nodes.description: The baby can sit up without support, using their hands for balance initially. This independent sitting milestone indicates improved core strength and balance, allowing the baby to play with toys in a seated position.
exitCriteria: Sits steadily for several minutes without support
signals: Sits with support easily
Begins to sit upright on their own for brief moments, using hands for balance
activities: Place interesting toys around the baby in a circle to encourage reaching and balancing while seated
Give the baby plenty of floor time to practice sitting up and adjusting their posture

_orig.name: Sits independently (unsupported)
exitCriteria: Sits steadily for several minutes without support
_orig.description: The baby can sit up without support, using their hands for balance initially. This independent sitting milestone indicates improved core strength and balance, allowing the baby to play with toys in a seated position.
signals: Sits with support easily
Begins to sit upright on their own for brief moments, using hands for balance
activities: Place interesting toys around the baby in a circle to encourage reaching and balancing while seated
Give the baby plenty of floor time to practice sitting up and adjusting their posture

nodes.name: Stands with support (bears weight)
nodes.description: Held under the arms or against a surface, the baby can bear some weight on their legs. This supported standing is an early step toward pulling up and standing independently, helping to strengthen leg muscles and accustom the baby to upright posture.
exitCriteria: Stands while holding on, bearing weight on legs
signals: Sits independently easily
Begins to push legs against a surface when feet are placed down (enjoys "standing" with support)
activities: Hold the baby in a standing position on your lap or the floor to let them feel their legs supporting weight
Use a stable surface (like a sofa) and help the baby stand against it for short intervals, always supervising closely

_orig.name: Stands with support (bears weight)
exitCriteria: Stands while holding on, bearing weight on legs
_orig.description: Held under the arms or against a surface, the baby can bear some weight on their legs. This supported standing is an early step toward pulling up and standing independently, helping to strengthen leg muscles and accustom the baby to upright posture.
signals: Sits independently easily
Begins to push legs against a surface when feet are placed down (enjoys "standing" with support)
activities: Hold the baby in a standing position on your lap or the floor to let them feel their legs supporting weight
Use a stable surface (like a sofa) and help the baby stand against it for short intervals, always supervising closely

nodes.name: Bounces when held standing
nodes.description: When supported in a standing position, the baby begins to push up and down with their legs (bouncing). This playful movement shows increased leg strength and enjoyment of bearing weight. Caregivers often notice the baby wants to "dance" or bounce when held upright.
exitCriteria: Bounces on legs with adult support
signals: Stands with support (bears weight) easily
Begins to push up and down with legs (as if doing mini squats) while being held in standing
activities: Hold the baby securely and let them bounce on your lap or the floor, making it a fun game
Play gentle music and bounce the baby to the rhythm while supporting under their arms

_orig.name: Bounces when held standing
exitCriteria: Bounces on legs with adult support
_orig.description: When supported in a standing position, the baby begins to push up and down with their legs (bouncing). This playful movement shows increased leg strength and enjoyment of bearing weight. Caregivers often notice the baby wants to "dance" or bounce when held upright.
signals: Stands with support (bears weight) easily
Begins to push up and down with legs (as if doing mini squats) while being held in standing
activities: Hold the baby securely and let them bounce on your lap or the floor, making it a fun game
Play gentle music and bounce the baby to the rhythm while supporting under their arms

nodes.name: Rocks on hands and knees (prepares to crawl)
nodes.description: The baby gets on all fours and begins rocking back and forth. This movement is a precursor to crawling, as it strengthens the muscles and develops the coordination needed to move forward or backward. Rocking builds the foundation for the babyâ€™s first crawling strides.
exitCriteria: Balances on hands and knees, rocking back and forth
signals: Sits independently easily
Begins to get into hands-and-knees position and rocks without moving forward
activities: Place toys just out of reach to encourage the baby to get on hands and knees and reach forward
Provide plenty of supervised floor time so the baby can experiment with moving in the crawling position

_orig.name: Rocks on hands and knees (prepares to crawl)
exitCriteria: Balances on hands and knees, rocking back and forth
_orig.description: The baby gets on all fours and begins rocking back and forth. This movement is a precursor to crawling, as it strengthens the muscles and develops the coordination needed to move forward or backward. Rocking builds the foundation for the babyâ€™s first crawling strides.
signals: Sits independently easily
Begins to get into hands-and-knees position and rocks without moving forward
activities: Place toys just out of reach to encourage the baby to get on hands and knees and reach forward
Provide plenty of supervised floor time so the baby can experiment with moving in the crawling position

nodes.name: Crawls (hands-and-knees mobility)
nodes.description: The infant begins to crawl forward on hands and knees. This classic crawling is a major mobility milestone, allowing the baby to explore their environment more freely. Crawling strengthens the whole body and also supports cross-coordination of arms and legs, which is important for later skills like walking and even bilateral brain coordination.
exitCriteria: Crawls on hands and knees, moving forward
signals: Rocks on hands and knees (prepares to crawl) easily
Begins to coordinate moving one arm and the opposite knee forward to crawl
activities: Create a safe, open play area to encourage lots of crawling practice
Place interesting objects or a caregiver at short distances to motivate the baby to crawl toward them

_orig.name: Crawls (hands-and-knees mobility)
exitCriteria: Crawls on hands and knees, moving forward
_orig.description: The infant begins to crawl forward on hands and knees. This classic crawling is a major mobility milestone, allowing the baby to explore their environment more freely. Crawling strengthens the whole body and also supports cross-coordination of arms and legs, which is important for later skills like walking and even bilateral brain coordination.
signals: Rocks on hands and knees (prepares to crawl) easily
Begins to coordinate moving one arm and the opposite knee forward to crawl
activities: Create a safe, open play area to encourage lots of crawling practice
Place interesting objects or a caregiver at short distances to motivate the baby to crawl toward them

nodes.name: Pulls to stand (holding onto support)
nodes.description: Using furniture or an adultâ€™s hands, the infant pulls themselves up from the floor into a standing position. Pulling to stand marks a transition to vertical mobility. It strengthens leg muscles further and is a necessary step toward cruising and independent standing.
exitCriteria: Pulls up to a standing position using furniture or support
signals: Crawls (hands-and-knees mobility) easily
Begins to grab onto low furniture (like a couch or coffee table) and pull up to stand, though may plop back down
activities: Place favorite toys on a low table or couch to motivate the baby to pull up to stand and reach
Ensure furniture is stable and childproof, as the baby will use it to pull up

_orig.name: Pulls to stand (holding onto support)
exitCriteria: Pulls up to a standing position using furniture or support
_orig.description: Using furniture or an adultâ€™s hands, the infant pulls themselves up from the floor into a standing position. Pulling to stand marks a transition to vertical mobility. It strengthens leg muscles further and is a necessary step toward cruising and independent standing.
signals: Crawls (hands-and-knees mobility) easily
Begins to grab onto low furniture (like a couch or coffee table) and pull up to stand, though may plop back down
activities: Place favorite toys on a low table or couch to motivate the baby to pull up to stand and reach
Ensure furniture is stable and childproof, as the baby will use it to pull up

nodes.name: Cruises along furniture
nodes.description: Holding onto furniture for support, the infant steps sideways, cruising from one spot to another. Cruising is a significant precursor to independent walking. It shows the baby can bear full weight on their legs while coordinating side-stepping motions, relying on support for balance.
exitCriteria: Side-steps while holding onto furniture (cruises at least a few steps)
signals: Pulls to stand (holding onto support) easily
Begins to shuffle sideways holding onto the couch or coffee table to reach a desired object
activities: Arrange stable furniture in a safe environment so the baby can cruise short distances along it
Encourage cruising by placing toys just out of reach along the edge of a sofa, prompting the baby to step sideways

_orig.name: Cruises along furniture
exitCriteria: Side-steps while holding onto furniture (cruises at least a few steps)
_orig.description: Holding onto furniture for support, the infant steps sideways, cruising from one spot to another. Cruising is a significant precursor to independent walking. It shows the baby can bear full weight on their legs while coordinating side-stepping motions, relying on support for balance.
signals: Pulls to stand (holding onto support) easily
Begins to shuffle sideways holding onto the couch or coffee table to reach a desired object
activities: Arrange stable furniture in a safe environment so the baby can cruise short distances along it
Encourage cruising by placing toys just out of reach along the edge of a sofa, prompting the baby to step sideways

nodes.name: Stands unsupported briefly
nodes.description: The infant can let go of support and stand on their own for a moment or two. This shows increasing balance and leg strength. Though they may quickly grab back on or plop down, these fleeting moments of independent standing are a big confidence booster and step toward taking first steps.
exitCriteria: Stands without holding on for a brief period (a few seconds)
signals: Cruises along furniture easily
Begins to stand up alone in the middle of the floor for a second or two before sitting down
activities: Encourage independent standing by positioning the child in standing and then briefly letting go (while staying ready to catch)
Make a game of standing up: sit on the floor facing the child and encourage them to stand and fall into your arms

_orig.name: Stands unsupported briefly
exitCriteria: Stands without holding on for a brief period (a few seconds)

Though they may quickly grab back on or plop down, these fleeting moments of independent standing are a big confidence booster and step toward taking first steps.

nodes.name: Takes first steps (with help or independently)
nodes.description: Around their first birthday, the infant may take their very first steps. Some need to hold a caregiverâ€™s hand (or push a walker toy) while others may attempt a step or two without support. These early steps are usually wobbly and few, but mark the start of independent walking.
exitCriteria: Takes at least a couple of steps forward (with or without assistance)
signals: Cruises along furniture easily
Begins to step forward when supported or occasionally lets go to try a step without holding on
activities: Hold the child's hands and let them walk toward you, or encourage them to move between two adults a short distance apart
Use push toys that provide support so the child can practice taking steps

_orig.name: Takes first steps (with help or independently)
exitCriteria: Takes at least a couple of steps forward (with or without assistance)
_orig.description: Around their first birthday, the infant may take their very first steps. Some need to hold a caregiverâ€™s hand (or push a walker toy) while others may attempt a step or two without support. These early steps are usually wobbly and few, but mark the start of independent walking.
signals: Cruises along furniture easily
Begins to step forward when supported or occasionally lets go to try a step without holding on
activities: Hold the child's hands and let them walk toward you, or encourage them to move between two adults a short distance apart

nodes.name: Walks independently
nodes.description: The toddler can walk without support. Independent walking may start with a wide stance and arms out for balance (the classic toddler waddle), but over weeks their gait steadies. This milestone opens up a new world of exploration, as the child can now move around upright.
exitCriteria: Walks alone for several steps
signals: Takes first steps (with help or independently) easily
Begins to walk across the room without holding onto anyone or anything (though may tumble)
activities: Provide a safe, open space for the toddler to practice walking; stay nearby to supervise
Play "come to me" games, encouraging the toddler to walk to you or between two caregivers

_orig.name: Walks independently
exitCriteria: Walks alone for several steps
_orig.description: The toddler can walk without support. Independent walking may start with a wide stance and arms out for balance (the classic toddler waddle), but over weeks their gait steadies. This milestone opens up a new world of exploration, as the child can now move around upright.
signals: Takes first steps (with help or independently) easily

activities: Provide a safe, open space for the toddler to practice walking; stay nearby to supervise

nodes.name: Climbs stairs (on knees or with help)
nodes.description: The toddler can navigate stairs by crawling up or stepping up with support. Initially, they might go up stairs on hands and knees or hold an adultâ€™s hand or the railing. Climbing stairs builds leg strength and coordination, though going down is usually harder and comes later.
exitCriteria: Ascends a few stairs using hands-and-knees or with minimal assistance
signals: Walks independently easily
Begins to attempt climbing up stairs (often crawling up or needing a hand to hold)
activities: Practice on a safe, shallow step or sturdy toddler stairs (always supervise closely)
Encourage crawling up steps as a game, and assist with coming down backwards until the child is ready

_orig.name: Climbs stairs (on knees or with help)
exitCriteria: Ascends a few stairs using hands-and-knees or with minimal assistance
_orig.description: The toddler can navigate stairs by crawling up or stepping up with support. Initially, they might go up stairs on hands and knees or hold an adultâ€™s hand or the railing. Climbing stairs builds leg strength and coordination, though going down is usually harder and comes later.

nodes.name: Runs (fast toddler walk)
nodes.description: The toddlerâ€™s walk transitions into a runâ€”essentially a quicker, less steady gait. At this stage, their running is more of a hurried toddle with frequent falls as they learn to coordinate speed and balance. This milestone shows growing confidence and leg strength.
exitCriteria: Runs forward unaided (may still fall or bump often)
signals: Walks independently easily
Begins to move at a faster pace, transitioning from walking to a hurried run (often with arms out for balance)
activities: Play chase or running games in a safe, open area to give your toddler practice moving faster
Provide a soft, grassy space if possible â€“ this way falls are cushioned as they learn to run

_orig.name: Runs (fast toddler walk)
exitCriteria: Runs forward unaided (may still fall or bump often)
_orig.description: The toddlerâ€™s walk transitions into a runâ€”essentially a quicker, less steady gait. At this stage, their running is more of a hurried toddle with frequent falls as they learn to coordinate speed and balance. This milestone shows growing confidence and leg strength.
signals: Walks independently easily
Begins to move at a faster pace, transitioning from walking to a hurried run (often with arms out for balance)
activities: Play chase or running games in a safe, open area to give your toddler practice moving faster
Provide a soft, grassy space if possible â€“ this way falls are cushioned as they learn to run

nodes.name: Climbs up and down furniture
nodes.description: The toddler becomes adept at climbing onto couches, chairs, or playground equipment. They can pull themselves up and also carefully ease themselves back down. This climbing skill reflects upper and lower body strength, coordination, and a fearless curiosity (which means caregivers must be extra watchful!).
exitCriteria: Climbs onto low furniture or play equipment and gets down again safely
signals: Climbs stairs (on knees or with help) easily
Begins to scramble onto the couch or bed and attempts to get down feet-first
activities: Create a safe climbing environment: for instance, cushions on the floor or a low toddler slide
Teach safe climbing practices (like turning around to descend feet first) as they explore furniture

_orig.name: Climbs up and down furniture
exitCriteria: Climbs onto low furniture or play equipment and gets down again safely
_orig.description: The toddler becomes adept at climbing onto couches, chairs, or playground equipment. They can pull themselves up and also carefully ease themselves back down. This climbing skill reflects upper and lower body strength, coordination, and a fearless curiosity (which means caregivers must be extra watchful!).
signals: Climbs stairs (on knees or with help) easily
Begins to scramble onto the couch or bed and attempts to get down feet-first
activities: Create a safe climbing environment: for instance, cushions on the floor or a low toddler slide
Teach safe climbing practices (like turning around to descend feet first) as they explore furniture

nodes.name: Kicks a ball
nodes.description: The toddler can kick a stationary ball. Initially, they may just walk into the ball or use a stiff leg, but gradually they learn to swing the foot. Kicking a ball requires balance on one leg momentarily and coordination to contact the ball, marking growing athletic ability.
exitCriteria: Kicks a ball forward at least a small distance
signals: Runs (fast toddler walk) easily
Begins to attempt kicking objects on the ground, even if they miss or fall after kicking
activities: Play simple ball games: roll a ball and encourage the child to kick it back to you
Hold the toddlerâ€™s hand if needed and help them swing their foot to kick a lightweight ball

_orig.name: Kicks a ball
exitCriteria: Kicks a ball forward at least a small distance
_orig.description: The toddler can kick a stationary ball. Initially, they may just walk into the ball or use a stiff leg, but gradually they learn to swing the foot. Kicking a ball requires balance on one leg momentarily and coordination to contact the ball, marking growing athletic ability.
signals: Runs (fast toddler walk) easily
Begins to attempt kicking objects on the ground, even if they miss or fall after kicking
activities: Play simple ball games: roll a ball and encourage the child to kick it back to you
Hold the toddlerâ€™s hand if needed and help them swing their foot to kick a lightweight ball

nodes.name: Throws a ball (overhand)
nodes.description: The toddler can throw a ball forward, using an overhand motion (raising the arm and releasing). At first the ball may just drop or go a short distance, but the action of throwing indicates improved arm coordination and the understanding of object projection. This skill often develops alongside kicking and other simple ball play.
exitCriteria: Throws a ball forward a few feet (any overhand motion)
signals: Runs (fast toddler walk) easily
Begins to enjoy tossing toys or balls, even if they just go forward a short distance
activities: Provide soft balls or beanbags and show the toddler how to throw overhand by modeling the motion
Make a target game: set a bucket and encourage the child to throw balls into it, to practice aim

_orig.name: Throws a ball (overhand)

nodes.name: Jumps in place (two feet off ground)
nodes.description: The young child learns to jump, getting both feet briefly off the ground. Early jumps may barely lift off, but the act of taking off and landing demonstrates growing leg power and coordination. Jumping is a playful milestone that often emerges as kids mimic frogs or dance to music. It also reflects confidence in balanceâ€”since they have to land without toppling.
exitCriteria: Performs a two-footed jump, both feet leaving the ground together
signals: Runs (fast toddler walk) easily
Begins to crouch and spring upward, attempting to jump (often with one foot leading or only a tiny hop at first)
activities: Hold the child's hands and practice jumping together, saying "1-2-3 jump!"
Make a game of jumping: e.g., jump over a line on the ground or like a bunny; show how to bend knees and push up

nodes.name: Walks up stairs alternating feet (with rail)
nodes.description: By 2Â½-3 years, the child can ascend stairs one foot per step while holding onto a railing or an adultâ€™s hand. Alternating feet (instead of both feet on each step) is a coordination leap, indicating improved strength and balance. They typically still descend one step at a time (marking time) until later.
exitCriteria: Goes up an entire flight with alternate feet, using a rail for support
signals: Climbs up and down furniture easily
Begins to step with alternate feet going upstairs when hand or railing is available (though may revert to both feet per step if tired or unsupported)
activities: Practice stair-climbing during daily routines, always with supervision; encourage using alternate feet going up while holding the rail
Play "follow the leader" on stairs, demonstrating stepping one foot per step

nodes.name: Balances on one foot (few seconds)
nodes.description: At around 3 years old, the child can stand on one foot briefly. This balancing skillâ€”perhaps demonstrated in games like hopping or imitating flamingosâ€”shows significant development in lower body strength and stability. Being able to balance on one foot for even 2-3 seconds is a precursor to hopping on one foot and more advanced coordination.
exitCriteria: Stands on one foot for at least 2 seconds without support
signals: Jumps in place (two feet off ground) easily
Begins to lift one foot and balance briefly when playing (might hold arms out or wobble)
activities: Make a game of balance: see if the child can be a flamingo on one foot, or play stop-and-go games where they freeze on one foot
Practice balance on lines or low beams at the playground (with close supervision) to build confidence

nodes.name: Hops on one foot
nodes.description: By 3 years and beyond, the child can hop forward on one foot, though they might manage only one or two hops in a row at first. Hopping requires explosive leg strength and excellent balance, as well as the coordination to land on the same foot repeatedly. Mastery of hopping is a strong indicator of gross motor development in the preschool years.
exitCriteria: Hops forward on one foot for at least 1-2 hops
signals: Balances on one foot (few seconds) easily
Begins to hop forward on one foot, though may manage only one or two hops at first
activities: Practice hopping during outdoor play: hold the child's hand initially while they hop on one foot
Set hopping challenges, like "Can you hop like a bunny on one foot?" or use hopscotch grids to make it fun

nodes.name: Swipes at dangling objects
nodes.description: Lying on their back, the infant swats at toys or objects hanging above them (like a mobile). These swiping motions are an early form of voluntary arm movement and hand-eye coordination.
exitCriteria: Bats at a hanging toy repeatedly
signals: Birth: Reflexive responses easily
Begins to swipe at toys overhead, sometimes making contact
activities: Provide safe objects of various sizes to grasp and explore
Play games that involve picking up, dropping, or stacking objects

nodes.name: Reaches for objects intentionally
nodes.description: The infant begins to reach out deliberately to grab or touch objects within view. This marks a shift from reflexive batting to purposeful fine motor control guided by vision.
exitCriteria: Successfully reaches and touches a desired object
signals: Swipes at dangling objects easily
Begins to reach out toward toys, sometimes grasping them briefly
activities: Provide safe objects of various sizes to grasp and explore
Play games that involve picking up, dropping, or stacking objects

nodes.name: Grasps objects with palm
nodes.description: Using a raking motion of the whole hand, the baby can close their fingers around a toy and hold it in their palm (palmar grasp). This skill shows increasing hand strength and control.
exitCriteria: Grasps a toy in palm for a few seconds
signals: Reaches for objects intentionally easily
Begins to grasp toys placed in hand, though grip may be fleeting
activities: Provide safe objects of various sizes to grasp and explore
Play games that involve picking up, dropping, or stacking objects

nodes.name: Transfers object hand-to-hand
nodes.description: The baby can move an object from one hand to the other hand. Transferring items shows improved coordination and that the two sides of the body (and brain) are communicating. This skill is often observed when a baby picks up a toy in one hand and then brings it to the other.
exitCriteria: Moves a held object to the other hand intentionally
signals: Grasps objects with palm easily
Begins to pass toys from one hand to the other during play
activities: Provide safe objects of various sizes to grasp and explore

nodes.name: Raking grasp of small objects
nodes.description: Using all fingers in a scratching motion, the baby can rake small objects toward themselves and pick them up. The raking grasp is a common way infants pick up finger foods or tiny toys before they develop the precision of the thumb-and-forefinger pincer grasp.
exitCriteria: Rakes a small item toward self and picks it up
signals: Transfers object hand-to-hand easily
Begins to use fingers to rake small bits (like cereal) into their hand
activities: Provide safe objects of various sizes to grasp and explore

nodes.name: Crude pincer grasp (thumb and side of finger)
nodes.description: The infant begins using the thumb in opposition to the fingers. In a crude pincer grasp, the thumb presses against the side of the index finger to hold small objects. exitCriteria: Uses thumb and another finger to hold a small object (clumsy pinch)

Begins to pick up little items using thumb against the side of forefinger (rather than in palm)
activities: Provide safe objects of various sizes to grasp and explore
Play games that involve picking up, dropping, or stacking objects

Itâ€™s crucial for self-feeding small foods and later skills like holding writing tools.

Begins to precisely pinch small objects between the pads of thumb and index finger

nodes.name: Puts objects into a container
nodes.description: The infant/toddler loves putting toys into boxes or containers (and dumping them out). This simple play behavior is actually a fine motor and cognitive skill, requiring grasp and release control as well as understanding of in/out.
exitCriteria: Places at least 3 objects into a container
signals: Transfers object hand-to-hand easily
Begins to enjoy dropping items into a box or bowl, then tipping them out
activities: Give the child a box and several toys to encourage filling and dumping (great for cause and effect learning)
Play clean-up games where you both put blocks into a bin, reinforcing this skill

Begins to scribble on paper when given a crayon (lots of random lines and dots)

nodes.name: Feeds self finger foods
nodes.description: Using their developing grasp, the baby can pick up small bits of food (like cereal or fruit pieces) and feed themselves. Finger feeding allows them to participate in meals and signals readiness for more self-feeding practice.

Begins to successfully get tiny snacks (like puffs) into their own mouth using their hands

nodes.name: Uses spoon or cup with assistance

nodes.name: Follows simple one-step instructions with gestures
nodes.description: The young toddler can carry out basic directions especially when given with a pointing gesture or demonstration. For example, you might say "Go get the ball" while pointing, and they will retrieve it. They rely on both the verbal cue and the nonverbal gesture to understand what to do.

signals: Understands a few common words (e.g., "no", "bye-bye") easily
Begins to follow very basic instructions when context or gestures help (e.g., hands you an item when you hold out your hand and say "give me")
activities: Play simple games like "Give it to me" or "Bring the ball" using gestures to encourage the child to follow through
Use consistent phrases for routine instructions ("Sit down", "Come here") and model the action to help them learn

nodes.name: Notices rhymes or repeated sounds in words
nodes.description: Toward the end of this age range, the child develops phonological awareness. They might giggle at rhyming words or point out repeated starting sounds (alliteration). For example, they may notice that "cat" and "hat" sound the same at the end, or laugh at tongue-twisters. This sensitivity to sound patterns is a foundation for literacy, indicating the child hears the smaller components of words.
exitCriteria: Points out or reacts to rhyming words or alliterations in everyday speech or songs
signals: Understands most everyday conversations easily
Begins to show excitement or recognition when hearing rhyming phrases (like in nursery rhymes) or words that start with the same sound
activities: Play rhyming games ("What rhymes with cat? Hat and cat rhyme!") and read rhyming books to draw attention to word endings

nodes.name: Laughs and squeals
nodes.description: By around 4-6 months, babies show delight through laughter and high-pitched squeals. They might laugh when tickled or during a game of peekaboo. These sounds are social signals of joy and invite continued interaction from caregivers. Giggling reflects emotional development and burgeoning social communication.

Begins to giggle or squeal in response to playful actions (like kisses on the tummy or silly faces)

Use toys that make gentle surprising actions (like a soft jack-in-the-box) to elicit squeals of joy and repeat as long as theyâ€™re interested

nodes.name: Imitates sounds or gestures
nodes.description: The infant/toddler begins actively copying others. They may mimic a caregiverâ€™s cough, attempt to say a sound they just heard, or copy simple gestures like waving. nodes.name: Uses ~5â€“10 words

By around 15-18 months, the toddler typically has about 5-10 words they use meaningfully (though pronunciation might be approximate). nodes.name: Frequently asks "why" questions

nodes.name: Smiles in response to caregiver (social smile)
nodes.description: At around 6-8 weeks, the baby begins to smile deliberately in response to people, not just from internal reflexes. This social smile is a major milestone indicating they are engaging with and enjoying interactions. Itâ€™s often triggered by a caregiverâ€™s face or voice and serves to bond baby and caregiver, as each smile encourages more warmth and attention.

signals: Birth: Reflexive responses easily
Begins to give big, genuine grins when someone they know smiles or plays with them (especially caregivers)

Use the social smile moments to further engage: play simple games like smiling then sticking out your tongue â€“ babies often smile and may even try to imitate fun expressions

nodes.name: Shows preference for familiar caregivers
nodes.description: The baby clearly favors their primary caregivers, often parents. They may become upset when handed to an unfamiliar person or calm more quickly with a known voice. This preference is a sign of healthy attachment forming â€“ the baby has learned who provides comfort and security, and they show a strong bias towards those individuals.
exitCriteria: Calms or brightens noticeably more with familiar people than with strangers
signals: Smiles in response to caregiver (social smile) easily
Begins to settle more quickly for a parent or cry when that parent leaves the room (versus being held by someone they donâ€™t recognize well)
activities: Allow the baby to have consistent quality time with a few primary caregivers; consistency helps them form strong attachments
If introducing new people, do so gradually and in presence of a trusted caregiver. For example, let a grandparent play alongside you before they try holding the baby, to ease the babyâ€™s comfort

nodes.name: Seeks comfort from caregivers when upset

This shows they have formed a clear attachment and expect safety from specific people. Itâ€™s evident by about 6 months that they know who to go to for soothing, rather than being comforted by anyone. This marks a deepening of the trust bond.

As mobility increases (rolling, crawling), notice how they come toward you for reassurance in unfamiliar settings; be available with hugs or calming words

nodes.name: Explores away from caregiver but checks back
nodes.description: The toddler uses the caregiver as a secure base. They will venture out to examine a toy or another person, but regularly glance back at their caregiver or periodically return for a quick touch-base (like a hug or look) before heading off again. This behavior shows a balance of growing independence with continued attachmentâ€” they feel safe enough to explore because they know their caregiver is there.
exitCriteria: Frequently looks at or returns to caregiver briefly while playing at a distance
signals: Seeks comfort from caregivers when upset easily
Begins to wander into another room or across the playground, but will periodically run back or call out to make sure caregiver is still near
activities: Encourage exploration in safe environments: let them play across the room or in a baby-proof park area while you watch; smile or acknowledge them when they â€œcheck inâ€ with eye contact or by bringing you a toy

Play games that involve distance but reassurance: e.g., play chase where they run and you playfully catch (so they know youâ€™ll always come get them), or hide-and-seek where they find you quickly (showing itâ€™s safe even if you disappear momentarily)

nodes.name: Expresses a range of basic emotions
nodes.description: By about 1 year, the child openly expresses a range of basic emotions. They grin or laugh when joyful, may throw a brief tantrum or cry when frustrated, and might show fear by clinging during loud noises or new situations. This emotional expressiveness reflects both temperament and development â€“ theyâ€™re experiencing feelings intensely and learning to express them (though not yet to manage them). Caregivers start to see distinct personality traits emerging.
exitCriteria: Clearly exhibits happiness, anger, fear, etc., through facial expressions and behavior
signals: Seeks comfort from caregivers when upset easily
Begins to have more noticeable mood swings or reactions: e.g., beams with pride after a new skill, throws toys when angry that something wonâ€™t work, hides face when scared
activities: Label their emotions when you notice them ("You look happy!", "I see youâ€™re mad the block tower fell"); this validates their feelings and teaches emotion vocabulary

Stay calm and offer comfort during emotional outbursts; gently narrate what might help ("I know, itâ€™s upsetting when the toy breaks. Letâ€™s ask for help or try again together") to start building coping strategies

nodes.name: Notices and smiles at other children
nodes.description: By around 6 months, babies become very interested in other babies and children. They may stare, smile, or reach toward a peer. This peer interest is the start of socialization, indicating they recognize other little people as appealing. They often light up when seeing a baby face in a mirror or a real infant peer, sometimes even trying to babble or interact. Itâ€™s a delightful milestone where social motivation extends beyond caregivers.
exitCriteria: Frequently observes or reacts positively to seeing other infants/children
signals: Smiles in response to caregiver (social smile) easily
Begins to fixate on other children in the vicinity, smiling or becoming excited when a sibling or baby friend comes into view
activities: Arrange playdates or attend baby groups so they can see others; even if they donâ€™t â€œplayâ€ together yet, they benefit from seeing peers
Mirror fun: seat them in front of a mirror or with another baby and let them see each other move; often theyâ€™ll smile or coo in response. Encourage gentle touches if they reach out

nodes.name: Plays alongside other children (parallel play)
nodes.description: The young toddler will play in the presence of other children (often with similar toys), but not directly with them. This side-by-side play is called parallel play. Theyâ€™re interested in what the other is doing and may mimic them, but thereâ€™s not much interaction yet beyond occasional grabs or exchanges. Parallel play is a normal stage that precedes more interactive play and indicates theyâ€™re comfortable around peers, even if theyâ€™re not truly cooperating yet.
exitCriteria: Comfortably plays near other children without a lot of direct interaction
signals: Notices and smiles at other children easily
Begins to spend time with kids in the same area, playing separately but often watching or imitating each other (might each be stacking blocks independently, for example)
activities: Provide opportunities for your child to be around peers (playgroups, playgrounds). Donâ€™t force sharing at this stage but supervise for any aggressive behaviors
Place similar toys when kids are together so they can each have one (two sets of blocks, etc.). Theyâ€™ll observe one another and may take cuesâ€”this builds comfort and interest in peers

nodes.name: Interacts briefly with peers (offers toys, imitates)
nodes.description: The toddler starts to have fleeting interactions with other children. They may hand a toy to a peer, imitate what the other is doing, or chase around briefly. These interactions are still simple and often not sustained, but they signal the beginning of social play. The toddler is learning the basics of sharing space and objects with others, even if they donâ€™t yet grasp turn-taking or sustained cooperation.
exitCriteria: Engages in short play exchanges with another child (e.g., gives a toy or mimics an action)
signals: Plays alongside other children (parallel play) easily
Begins to occasionally approach a peer: might offer a toy (or grab one), mimic their play style, or follow each other around for a minute
activities: Encourage gentle interactions during playdates: if they hand a toy to a friend, praise their sharing; if they imitate a friendâ€™s silly dance, join in to make it a fun group moment

Guide but donâ€™t micromanage. For instance, you can initiate a simple game like rolling a ball between them. If interactions go awry (snatching or hitting), intervene calmly to model appropriate behavior

nodes.name: Takes turns during play with help
nodes.description: As the toddler nears 3, they begin to grasp turn-taking in play (with adult guidance). For example, rolling a ball back and forth or waiting briefly while someone else goes down a slide. They often need reminders and may not like waiting, but this emerging skill indicates theyâ€™re learning social rules. Itâ€™s an important step toward cooperative playâ€” learning that play can be back-and-forth rather than just parallel.
exitCriteria: Participates in simple back-and-forth play (like rolling a ball) when guided
signals: Interacts briefly with peers (offers toys, imitates) easily
Begins to allow another child a turn in very basic games when an adult is mediating (e.g., will hand over a block when asked, then expect it back for their turn)
activities: Model turn-taking with games: "My turn to stack a block, now your turn." Use simple language and gestures to indicate turns, praising them when they wait and then get their go

Use a timer or counting for popular toys: "Let's let Sam have the car until I count to 10, then it's your turn." This concrete structure often helps toddlers accept waiting (since they can see an end in sight)

nodes.name: Plays cooperatively with peers
nodes.description: By 3-4 years old, children start engaging in true cooperative play. They have shared goals or storylines (like building something together or role-playing in a game of house). They communicate about the play, assign roles, or take turns more spontaneously. This stage indicates significant social maturity and ability to understand others' perspectives during play.
exitCriteria: Initiates or joins group play scenarios with roles or shared themes
signals: Takes turns during play with help easily

Begins to plan out play with another child (e.g., "You be the mommy, I'll be the daddy" or "Let's build a castle, you do this side I'll do that side") and mostly follows through without adult direction
activities: Offer props and opportunities for pretend play in small groups (dress-up clothes, play kitchen, building forts). Step back and observe as they often naturally negotiate roles in imaginative play

When minor conflicts arise in cooperative play, encourage them to resolve with prompts ("How can we make sure everyone has fun?" or "What could you say to ask for a turn?") rather than solving it for them, to build their social problem-solving skills
